definition.doc: Results of a paraprobe-intersector tool run.

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: Version specifier of this application definition.

field.name: definition
field.doc: Official NeXus NXDL schema with which this file was written.

field.name: program
field.doc: Given name of the program/software/tool with which this NeXus (configuration) file was generated.

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: Ideally program version plus build number, or commit hash or description of ever persistent resources where the source code of the program and build instructions can be found so that the program can be configured ideally in such a manner that the result of this computational process is recreatable in the same deterministic manner.

field.name: analysis_identifier
field.doc: Ideally, a (globally persistent) unique identifier for referring to this analysis.

field.name: analysis_description
field.doc: Possibility for leaving a free-text description about this analysis.

field.name: start_time
field.doc: ISO 8601 formatted time code with local time zone offset to UTC information included when the analysis behind this results file was started, i.e. the paraprobe-tool executable started as a process.

field.name: end_time
field.doc: ISO 8601 formatted time code with local time zone offset to UTC information included when the analysis behind this results file were completed and the paraprobe-tool executable exited as a process.

field.name: config_filename
field.doc: The absolute path and name of the config file for this analysis.

attribute.name: version
attribute.doc: At least SHA256 strong hash of the specific config_file for tracking provenance.

field.name: results_path
field.doc: Path to the directory where the tool should store NeXus/HDF5 results of this analysis. If not specified results will be stored in the current working directory.

group.doc: If used, contact information and eventually details of at least the person who performed this analysis.
Details about the coordinate system conventions used.

* paraprobe * lab * specimen * laser * leap * detector * recon

group.name: VOLUME_VOLUME_SPATIAL_CORRELATION
group.doc: The results of an overlap/intersection analysis.

field.name: current_to_next_link
field.doc: A matrix of feature_identifier which specifies which named features from the current set have directed link(s) pointing to which named feature(s) from the next set.

field.name: current_to_next_link_type
field.doc: For each link/pair in current_to_next a characterization whether the link is due to a volumetric overlap (0x00 == 0), proximity (0x01 == 1), or something else unknown (0xFF == 255).

field.name: next_to_current_link
field.doc: A matrix of feature_identifier which specifies which named feature(s) from the next set have directed link(s) pointing to which named feature(s) from the current set. Only if the mapping whereby the links is symmetric next_to_current maps the links in current_to_next in the opposite direction.

field.name: next_to_current_link_type
field.doc: For each link/pair in next_to_current a characterization whether the link is due to a volumetric overlap (0x00 == 0), proximity (0x01 == 1), or something else unknown (0xFF == 255).

field.name: intersection_volume
field.doc: For each pair of links in current_to_next the volume of the intersection, i.e. how much volume do the two features share. If features do not intersect the volume is zero.

group.name: coprecipitation_analysis
group.doc:
During coprecipitation analysis the current and next set are analyzed for links in a special way. Three set comparisons are made. Members of the set in each comparison are analyzed for overlap and proximity:
The first comparison is the current_set against the current_set. The second comparison is the next_set against the next_set. The third comparison is the current_set against the next_set.
Once the (forward) links for these comparisons are ready the pair relations are analyzed with respect to which feature identifier cluster in identifier space. Thereby a logical connection (link) is established between the features in the current_set and next_set. Recall that these two set typically represent different features within an observed system for otherwise the same parameterization. Examples include two sets of e.g. precipitates with differing chemical composition that were characterized in the same material volume representing a snapshot of an e.g. microstructure at the same point in time. Researchers may have performed two analyses, one to characterize precipitates A and another one to characterize percipitates B. Coprecipitation analysis now logically connects these independent characterization results to establish spatial correlations of e.g. precipitates spatial arrangement.

field.name: current_set_feature_to_cluster
field.doc: Matrix of feature_identifier and cluster_identifier pairs which encodes the cluster to which each feature_identifier was assigned. Here for features of the current_set.

field.name: next_set_feature_to_cluster
field.doc: Matrix of feature_identifier and cluster_identifier pairs which encodes the cluster to which each feature_identifier was assigned. Here for features of the next_set.

field.name: cluster_identifier
field.doc: The identifier (names) of the cluster.

field.name: cluster_composition
field.doc: Pivot table as a matrix. The first column encodes how many members from the current_set are in each cluster, one row per cluster. The second column encodes how many members from the next_set are in each cluster, in the same row per cluster respectively. The last column encodes the total number of members in the cluster.

field.name: cluster_statistics
field.doc: Pivot table as a matrix. The first column encodes the different types of clusters based on their number of members in the sub-graph. The second column encodes how many clusters with as many members exist.
